T1.question: Q1. The solar system is approximately 4.6 billion years old.

T2.question: Q2. Galaxies typically form disc-shaped structures.

T3.question: Q3. Rock can remain solid at higher temperatures than ice.

T4.question: Q4. Angular momentum increases as a collapsing gas cloud spins faster.

T5.question: Q5. Stars form through the collapse of isolated gas clouds in space.

T6.question: Q6. Planets in our solar system formed from the same gas and dust cloud as the Sun.

T7.question: Q7. The inner regions of the solar system are dominated by gas and ice.

T8.question: Q8. Stellar life cycles involve galactic recycling where dead stars fuel new star formation.

T9.question: Q9. Conservation of energy causes the center of a collapsing cloud to become hotter.

T10.question: Q10. All stars form independently without interacting with other stars.

T11.question: Q11. The solar system formed after the Big Bang.

T12.question: Q12. Angular momentum conservation flattens collapsing gas clouds into discs.

T13.question: Q13. New stars form at a rate of one per year in the Milky Way.

T14.question: Q14. Planets form after their host stars have already completed their life cycles.

T15.question: Q15. Observing other planetary systems helps understand our solar system's formation.

T16.question: Testing user input when quiz is over
